case_vignette: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of a painless, nonpruritic skin lesion on her right thigh. She initially thought it was an insect bite, but it has slowly increased in size over the past weeks. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule. When the skin lesion is squeezed, the surface retracts inwards. A photograph of the lesion is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painless spot on my right thigh that's been growing bigger over the last month.
How old are you?
I am 38 years old.
Do you have any history of skin conditions or skin cancer in your family?
I don't know about any skin conditions or skin cancer in my family.
Have you had any significant sun exposure or tanning bed use in the past?
I don't have that information.
Understood. Have you noticed any changes in the color or texture of the spot on your thigh?
Yes, the spot has gotten darker and it sinks in when I squeeze it.
Do you have any other concerning skin lesions elsewhere on your body?
No, just the one on my thigh.
Are you currently taking any medications or supplements?
I don't have that information.
Understood. Based on your symptoms, I recommend you see a dermatologist for further evaluation. **Final Diagnosis:** Suspicious skin lesion, further evaluation needed for diagnosis.
